'''''Cantharellus subalbidus''''', the '''white chanterelle''', is a [[fungus]] native to [[California]] and the [[Pacific Northwest]] region of [[North America]]. It is a member of the genus ''[[Cantharellus]]'' along with other popular edible [[chanterelle]]s.  It is similar in appearance to other chanterelles except for its cream to white color and orange bruising.<ref name=plis04/>

''C. subalbidus'' may form a [[mycorrhiza|mycorrhizal association]] with species of [[Pinus|pine]], [[Tsuga|hemlock]], [[Pseudotsuga menziesii|Douglas-fir]], and [[Arbutus menziesii|Pacific madrone]].<ref name=amm09/><ref name=mykoweb/><ref name=arora86/>  ''C. subalbidus'' has been found to be more common in [[old-growth forest]]s than in younger forests.<ref name=dun06/>

==Similar species==
Several other species of chanterelle may be found in western North America:
*''[[Cantharellus californicus|C. californicus]]''
*''[[Cantharellus cascadensis|C. cascadensis]]''
*''[[Cantharellus cibarius|C. cibarius]]'' var. ''roseocanus''
*''[[Cantharellus formosus|C. formosus]]''

Additionally, ''[[Hygrophoropsis aurantiaca]]'', ''[[Chroogomphus|Chroogomphus tomentosus]]'', and species in the genera ''[[Craterellus]]'', ''[[Gomphus (fungus)|Gomphus]]'', ''[[Omphalotus]]'', and ''[[Polyozellus]]'' may have a somewhat similar appearance to ''C. subalbidus''.
